PROJECTS TAKEN.Description:
Developed a custom shell that supports command line editing, I/O redirection, history
features, and pipes in C.

PROJECTS TAKEN.Title of Project: Visibility regions in polygons: VC-dimensions and approximation algorithms
PROJECTS TAKEN.Description:
For a polygon P with n vertices, the vertex guarding problem asks for the mini-
mum subset C of P vertices such that every point in P is seen by at least one point
in C . This problem is NP-hard. The first approximation algorithm by Ghosh involves
decomposition of the polygon into O(n 4 ) convex components. This discretized prob-
lem can then be treated as an instance of the Set Cover problem and solved in O(n 5 )
time with a greedy O(logn)-approximation algorithm. Later King and Kirkpatrick pro-
posed a polynomial time algorithm for the construction an ε-net of size O( 1 ε log log 1 ε ) for
the instances of the Hitting Set problem associated with our guarding problem. Using
Br onnimann
 ̈
and Goodrich’s algorithm they proposed the O(log log OPT ) approxima-
tion factor algorithm for vertex guard problem. Here we study the VC-dimension of
visibility systems in polygon with holes and show that the VC-dimension of is at least
7. Our study includes vertex guarding problems under different visibility definitions.
First we solve the vertex guarding problem under one specular reflection. Then we
consider art gallery problems under rectilinear visibility and present an O(n 2 )-time and
O(log n)-factor approximation algorithm for the vertex guarding problem. We present
a linear time algorithm for computing the visibility polygon under rectilinear visibility,
from an interior point. We also prove that the VC-dimension of visibility systems under
rectilinear visibility outside the minimum rectangle that encloses the points is d ∈ [4, 5].
For polygons with holes we show that the VC-dimension is at least 5.
